overview: Reduced Earnings Allowance can help if you income falls because of a work-related accident or disease - what you'll get, eligibility and how to claim
title: Reduced Earnings Allowance

table.body:
If you can't earn as much as you used to because of an accident or disease caused by your work, you could get up to £63.24 per week Reduced Earnings Allowance.

You can only get it for accidents that happened, or diseases that started, before 1 October 1990.

##Effect on other benefits

Reduced Earnings Allowance may affect any income-related benefits you or your partner are getting - [contact your local Jobcentre Plus](http://los.direct.gov.uk/default.aspx?type=2&lang=en "contact your local Jobcentre Plus"){:rel="external"} for details.

^You may also be able to get [Industrial Injuries Disablement Benefit](/industrial-injuries-disablement-benefit "Industrial Injuries Disablement Benefit").^
table.title: Overview

table.body:
£63.24 per week is the maximum rate. 

Your individual circumstances can affect the amount you get, eg whether or not you're working. 

Contact one of the [Industrial Injuries Disablement Benefit Centres](/reduced-earnings-allowance/further-information "Industrial Injuries Disablement Benefit Centres") for more information.

Reduced Earnings Allowance will be replaced by another benefit called Retirement Allowance if all the following apply:

- you get more than £2 a week Reduced Earnings Allowance 
- you reach State Pension age
- you're not in regular employment

##How you're paid

All benefits, pensions and allowances are paid [into an account](/how-to-have-your-benefits-paid "how to have your benefits paid"), eg your bank account.
table.title: What you'll get

table.body:
You could get Reduced Earnings Allowance if you're suffering from an illness or disability caused by a work-related accident or disease that happened before 1 October 1990.

You must also meet all of the following:

- your level of disability is assessed by a doctor to be at least 1% 
- you can't return to your regular occupation 
- you can't do other work with the same level of earnings as your regular occupation

##Going abroad

If you leave the UK to live permanently outside the European Economic Area (EEA), you won't be able to get Reduced Earnings Allowance.

The EEA includes:

- all [countries in the EU](http://europa.eu/about-eu/countries/index_en.htm "countries in the EU"){:rel="external"}
- Norway, Iceland and Liechtenstein

For temporary visits, you can usually claim for the first 3 months of your stay. 

This can be longer in special circumstances - check with the International Pensions Centre to see if you qualify.

$C**International Pensions Centre**  
**Telephone:** 0191 218 7777    
**Textphone:** 0191 218 7021    
Monday to Friday, 8am to 8pm$C

##Your circumstances change

Tell one of the [Industrial Injuries Disablement Benefit Centres](/reduced-earnings-allowance/further-information "Industrial Injuries Disablement Benefit Centres") straight away - eg if you stop or start work, change your occupation or the level of your earnings changes.

*[EEA]: European Economic Area
*[EU]: European Union
table.title: Eligibility

table.body:
Claim straight away or you might lose benefit - use form BI103. 

$D[Download 'Form BI103 - Reduced Earnings Allowance claim' (PDF, 239KB)](http://dwp.gov.uk/docs/bi103-print.pdf "Download 'Form BI103 - Reduced Earnings Allowance claim' (PDF, 239KB)"){:rel="external"}$D

The form comes with notes that will help you fill it in and tell you where to send it. 

You can also contact your regional [Industrial Injuries Disablement Benefit Centre](/reduced-earnings-allowance/further-information "Industrial Injuries Disablement Benefit Centre") for a claim form.

If you want help filling in your claim form, ring the Benefit Enquiry Helpline.

$C**Benefit Enquiry Helpline**  
**Telephone:** 0800 88 22 00  
**Textphone:** 0800 24 33 55  
Monday to Friday, 8:30am to 6:30pm$C
